STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 21, 2020
Jennifer DeVivo
Fostering Futures
Suite 260
2008 Hogback Road Suite 6
Ann Arbor, MI 48105
RE: License #: CB810302599
Fostering Futures
Suite 260
2008 Hogback Road Suite 6
Ann Arbor, MI 48105
Dear Ms. DeVivo:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 12/16/2020.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Identify why previous CAPs failed for repeat violations.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(a) Five social service workers per supervisor.
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
The agency was found to be in violation of the rule as determined by a review of
MDHHS caseload summaries pulled from October, August, and June 2020 as
directed by the MISEP. With a floor performance standard of 95%, the agency
averaged 88% for foster care caseloads, 72% for adoption caseloads, and 92% for
supervisory caseloads. REPEAT VIOALTION, Renewal Report 09/27/19, and
corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and Interim 11/26/18, and corresponding CAP,
01/08/19. The agency must report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will
ensure compliance.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(4) Before completion of the written report required by subrule (5
6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster parent with a
verbal summary of the preliminary findings at the conclusion of
the evaluation.
One of three licensing files reviewed did not document the verbal summary provided
to the foster parent as required.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
4

Five of eight foster care files reviewed were found to have missing and/or late
(beyond 30 days after completion) caregiver signatures on the treatment plans. One
of six applicable files was missing birth parent signatures on one plan. Additionally,
two files were found to have late supervisory approvals on two reports: one and two
days late respectively. REPEAT VIOALTION, Renewal Report 09/27/19, and
corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and Interim 11/26/18, and corresponding CAP,
01/08/19. The agency must report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will
ensure compliance.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(b) Name, known addresses and marital status of the child's
parents or legal guardian, if any.
(c) Names, ages, and known addresses of any siblings.
(b) Five of five applicable foster care files reviewed for initial placement
documentation were found to have not documented the required parent’s information
on the initial placement outline.
(c) Three of five applicable foster care files reviewed for initial placement
documentation were found not to have documented all required sibling information
on the initial placement outline.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason
why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s age,
appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417
5

(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the
change, except when prior notification would jeopardize the
child’s care or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the
agency shall notify the foster parent, at the time of the change,
why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning the
change in placement.
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
One of two foster care files reviewed for change in placement was found to have
documented the change (on the required DHHS 69) six months after the placement
change. This is a significant reduction in this requirement and the agency may
submit the last CAP as it appears to be working. REPEAT VIOALTION, Renewal
Report 09/27/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and Interim 11/26/18, and
corresponding CAP, 01/08/19. The agency must report why the previous CAPs
failed and how they will ensure compliance.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated. (DHHS
policy notes 12 months)
6

(c)(iii) One of eight foster care files was found to have an annual physical that was
completed two months late. This is an isolated incident and agency may submit the
same CAP as it appears it is working.
(f)(ii) One of two applicable foster care files was found to be overdue for an annual
dental exam. This youth last obtained a dental exam in 10/2018.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(a) One of three applicable foster care files reviewed for initial service plans
contained an initial plan completed three days late.
(b) One of eight foster care files reviewed for updated service plans contained one
updated plan completed one day late.
These are both isolated incidents and the agency may submit the previous CAP as it
appears to be working.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
7

Three of four closed foster care files reviewed were found to have DHHS 69s to
document the closings that were completed late (beyond the three days noted in
policy). One of the closing DHHS 69s did not have supervisory signature. REPEAT
VIOALTION, Renewal Report 09/27/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and
Interim 11/26/18, and corresponding CAP, 01/08/19. The agency must report why
the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.
Two of four adoption files reviewed for adoptive family evaluations had evaluations
completed late. The agency is advised to also review the reduced timeframes for
licensed foster parents who are adopting.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
One of three adoption files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
application was provided with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE ENGAGEMENT AND PLACEMENT
One of three unlicensed relative home placements reviewed was found to have:
8

 not completed criminal or central registry clearances on the relative
caregiver’s boyfriend who lived in the home initially and for about a year
after placement.
 not fully assessed the boyfriend on the initial 3130a (Relative Placement
Home Study) in all required areas.
 not assessed why the relative caregiver and boyfriend are no longer
residing together in the annual 3130a.
 not updated the relative caregiver’s address on the annual 3130a.
 not completed a 5770 (formerly 588) Relative Placement Safety Screen for
the relative caregiver’s move to a new home.
Note: Discussion on this case was held onsite with the agency and via email. A
safety plan was requested of the agency and they completed it on 12/14/20, noting
the boyfriend will not be alone with the youth at any time or sleep over at the home
until clearances are completed and assessed as appropriate. The safety plan was
observed in the youth’s MiSACWIS file and was signed by the relative caregiver.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
Seven of eight foster care files were found to have missing and/or late passports,
and/or passports unsigned by all required parties, and/or passports that were not
uploaded, and/or passport signatures that were not obtained timely. REPEAT
VIOALTION, Renewal Report 09/27/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and
Interim 11/26/18, and corresponding CAP, 01/08/19. The agency must report
why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Three of eight foster care files reviewed were found to have missing and/or late
FTMs, and/or FTM reports that were not uploaded or not signed. REPEAT
VIOALTION, Renewal Report 09/27/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and
Interim 11/26/18, and corresponding CAP, 01/08/19. The agency must report
why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Seven of eight foster care files were found to have case contacts entered after the
five days permitted in policy. These contacts were noted to be between one and
74 days late. Additionally, one isolated contact was observed to only say ‘Home
visit’ which does not meet the quality visit standards. Another contact misspelled
the caregiver’s name throughout the contact. REPEAT VIOALTION, Renewal
Report 09/27/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and Interim 11/26/18, and
corresponding CAP, 01/08/19. The agency must report why the previous
CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
9

ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment
Two of three adoption files reviewed for the child adoption assessment contained
assessments completed two days late. REPEAT VIOALTION, Renewal Report
09/27/19, and corresponding CAP, 10/11/19, and Interim 11/26/18, and
corresponding CAP, 01/08/19. The agency must report why the previous
CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
Two of three adoption files reviewed contained quarterly adoption reports (one in
each file) that were completed about a month late. One file contained quarterly
adoption reports with conflicting commitment dates. Additionally, one of the three
files contained one quarterly adoption report that only had the supervisor’s
signature.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 306
The agency was advised to ensure that old enrollments are closed. One
enrolled home was cited last year for not having application and orientation
documents and is still noted to not have the documents, although it remains
open. The agency reported that they have made attempts to close this enrolled
home with DCWL, however, the home reportedly remains on their list. The
agency is advised to document their attempts and maintain them in the event
there are questions on this at a later time.
R 325
The agency was advised to ensure they upload both the original 3706 and the
turnaround 3706 after it is processed, for verification of timeliness and signatures.
R 326
The agency was advised to ensure that the supervisors date all written
endorsements of initial and current reevaluations to clearly document when they
were endorsed. Additionally, the agency was advised to ensure they obtain annual
parent agency agreements for borrowed bed placements lasting over one year.
R 327
The agency was advised to ensure they clearly document what the foster parent is
told as it relates to advising them of the allegations. It was further recommended that
the agency not regularly allow foster parents to utilize one another as their support
person in situations where independent interviews are indicated.
10

R 421
The agency was advised to clearly document parenting time attempts and
cancellations or reasons why parenting time might not be occurring.
R 602, 603, 604, 702 and 707
The agency was advised to ensure timely uploading of adoption related documents.
This was related to one file.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was provided on where to upload the 30-day transfer plans for foster
care. The agency was uploading them to the initial, but they should be uploaded to
the current placement at the time the agency receives the case.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The agency was cited in special
investigation 2020C0207027, dated 08/11/20, for a violation of DHHS policy 722-
06H regarding visits with children in out of home care. The agency missed a face to
face visit with the youth within the first five days of placement. The agency submitted
a CAP, dated 08/20/20, and there were no noted violations of this requirement in this
inspection, therefore, it appears the agency has sufficiently implemented their CAP.
There were no safety concerns noted in the DCWL Field Analyst report.
There are 16 violations noted in this report when compared to 20 in the last
inspection. This indicates the agency is making efforts to implement their CAP and
has been effective in doing so. There are eight repeat violations that the agency is
advised to focus on during this next period.
11

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
December 18, 2020
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 21, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
12
